utterance: But you can't use them, my son.
speaker: his father

utterance: Anyhow, I can try.
speaker: Little Crotchet

utterance: It is a crotchet, but it will be no harm for him to try.
speaker: the doctors

utterance: It is a little crotchet, and he shall have the crutches.
speaker: his mother

utterance: I reckin if I had a pony that was n't afeard of nothin' I'd go right straight and find out where that fire is, and what it is.
speaker: Ben Gadsby

utterance: Why, Benjamin! Why, what on the face of the earth do you mean? Ride into that swamp! Why, you must have lost what little sense you had when you was born! I remember, jest as well as if it was day before yesterday, when Uncle Jimmy Cosby's red steer got in that swamp, and we could n't git him out. Git him out, did I say? We could n't even git nigh him. We could hear him beller, but we never got where we could see ha'r nor hide of him. If I was thirty year younger I'd take my foot in my hand and wade in there and see where the smoke comes from.
speaker: Mr. Jonathan Gadsby

utterance: If I had two good legs, I'd soon see what the trouble is.'
speaker: Little Crotchet

utterance: I believe I'll go in there and see where the fire is.
speaker: Ben Gadsby

utterance: Fire!
speaker: Mr. Jonathan Gadsby

utterance:
Who said anything about fire?
What living and moving creetur could build a fire in that thicket? I'd like mighty well to lay my eyes on him.
speaker: Mr. Jonathan Gadsby

utterance: Well, where you see smoke there's obliged to be fire. I've heard you say that yourself.
speaker: Ben Gadsby

utterance: Me?
speaker: Mr. Jonathan Gadsby

utterance:
Did I say that? Well, it was when I was n't so much as thinking that my two eyes were my own.
What about foxfire? Suppose that some quagmire or other in that there swamp has gone and got up a ruction on its own hook? Smoke without fire? Why, I've seed it many a time. And maybe that smoke comes from an eruption in the ground. What then? Who's going to know where the fire is ?
speaker: Mr. Jonathan Gadsby

utterance: Well, I can find bee-trees, and I'll find where that fire is.
speaker: Ben Gadsby

utterance: Well, sir, find out where the smoke comes from, and we'll not expect you to see the fire.'
speaker: Mr. Jonathan Gadsby

utterance: I wish I could go with you.
speaker: Little Crotchet

utterance: I don't need any company. I've done made up my mind, and I'm a-going to show the folks around here that where there's so much smoke there's obliged to be some fire.
speaker: Ben Gadsby

utterance: Well!
speaker: Ben Gadsby

utterance: I'm the biggest fool that ever walked the earth. If I ain't been asleep and dreamed all this, I'm crazy; and if I've been asleep, I'm a fool.
speaker: Ben Gadsby

utterance: What did you find?
speaker: Little Crotchet

utterance: Well, Nothing nothing at all.
speaker: Ben Gadsby

utterance: Nothing?
speaker: Little Crotchet

utterance: Why, you ought to have been with me! Why, I saw sights! The birds flew in my face, and when I got in the middle of the swamp a big white hog came rushing out, and if this Gray Pony had n't been the nimblest of his kind, you'd never have seen me any more.'
speaker: Little Crotchet

utterance:
Is that so? Well, I declare! 'T was all quiet with me.
I just went in and come out again, and that's all there is to it.
speaker: Ben Gadsby

utterance: I wish I'd been with you.
speaker: Little Crotchet

utterance: Good-by!
speaker: Little Crotchet

utterance: Well, by jing!
speaker: Ben Gadsby

utterance: It's nobody but me.
speaker: Little Crotchet

utterance: I was just laughing.
speaker: Little Crotchet

utterance: Good-night, my son, and God bless you!
speaker: Colonel Abercrombie

utterance: Good-night, father dear.
speaker: Little Crotchet

utterance:
The White Grunter carried his play too far.
He nipped a piece from my leg.
speaker: Aaron

utterance:
I never saw anything like it. I thought the White Pig was angry.
You did that to frighten Ben Gadsby.
speaker: Little Crotchet

utterance: Yes, Little Master, and I'm thinking the young man will never hunt for the smoke in the swamp any more.
speaker: Aaron

utterance: And when are you going home to your master?
speaker: Little Crotchet

utterance:
Never! He is no master of mine.
He is a bad man.
speaker: Aaron

utterance: They all love you because you are good, my son.
speaker: Mr. Abercrombie

utterance: Oh, no, father; it is n't that. It's because I am fond of them!
speaker: Little Crotchet

utterance: Help me off the horse. I have a headache sometimes, and I feel it coming on now. I want you to sit here and rub my head for me if you are not too tired.
speaker: Little Crotchet

utterance: What wid?
speaker: Big Sal

utterance: My han's too dirty.
speaker: Big Sal

utterance: You get the headache out, and I'll get the dirt off.
speaker: Little Crotchet

utterance: What are you crying about?
speaker: Little Crotchet

utterance: God A'mighty knows, honey. I'm des a-cryin', an' ef de angels fum heav'm wuz ter come down an' ax me, I couldn't tell um no mo'dan dat.
speaker: Big Sal

utterance: I reckon it's because you had the headache,
speaker: Little Crotchet

utterance: I speck so,
speaker: Big Sal

utterance: It looked like my head'd bust when you hollered at me, but de pain all done gone now.
speaker: Big Sal

utterance: I hope my head will quit aching presently. Sometimes it aches all night long.
speaker: Little Crotchet

utterance: I'm glad,
speaker: Little Crotchet

utterance: Well, suh!
speaker: Big Sal

utterance: You'll be feelin' mighty biggity now, I speck.
speaker: Uncle Turin

utterance: Who? Me?
speaker: Big Sal

utterance: God knows, I feel so little an' mean I could t'ar my ha'r out by de han❜ful.
speaker: Big Sal

utterance: Whar you been, Little Marster, dat we ain't seed you sence day 'fo' yistiddy?
speaker: unspecified

utterance: That's Randall's song. He sees the Little Master coming.
speaker: Aaron

utterance: I wish I wuz a runaway nigger!
speaker: Uncle Fountain

utterance: No, you don't!
speaker: Randall

utterance: Yes, I does
speaker: Uncle Fountain

utterance: How come?
speaker: Randall

utterance: Kaze den I'd have Little Marster runnin'atter me ev'y chance he got.
speaker: Uncle Fountain

utterance: Go 'way, nigger man! You'd have Jim Simmons's nigger dogs atter you, an' den what 'd you do?
speaker: Randall

utterance: Dat ar Aaron had um atter 'im, an' what'd he do?
speaker: Uncle Fountain

utterance: De Lord, He knows, -I don't! But don't you git de consate in yo' min' dat you kin do what Aaron done done, kaze you'll fool yo'se'f, sho!
speaker: Randall

utterance: What Aaron done done?
speaker: Uncle Fountain

utterance: He done fool dem ar nigger dogs; dat what he done done.
speaker: Randall

utterance: Den how come I can't fool dem ar dogs?
speaker: Uncle Fountain

utterance: How come? Well, you des try um one time, mo' speshully dat ar col'-nose dog, which he name Soun'.
speaker: Randall

utterance: Well, I ain't bleege ter try it when de white folks treat me right,
speaker: Uncle Fountain

utterance: Dat what make I say what I does. When you know 'zactly what you got, an' when you got mighty nigh what you want, dat's de time ter lay low an' say nothin'. Hit's some trouble ter git de corn off'n de cob, but spozen dey want no corn on de cob, what den ?
speaker: Randall

utterance: Honey, ain't it de trufe?
speaker: Uncle Fountain

utterance: Oho! what queer country is this, where all the birds are headless? If I'm to live here in peace, I must do as the brethren do.
speaker: The stranger

utterance: Queerer still, Here is a bird that has no head, and he can sing.
speaker: The stranger

utterance: Good-evening, sir, I see that the birds in this country have no heads.
speaker: The stranger

utterance: I presume, sir, that I ought to get rid of my head if I am to stay here, and I have nowhere else to go. How am I to do it?
speaker: The stranger

utterance: Easy enough, Birds that are so unfortunate as to have heads frequently come to me for relief. May I examine your neck to see what can be done?
speaker: the Wildcat

utterance: Shall I use a club on you, White Grunter? Shall I make bacon of you? You heard him call my name.
speaker: Aaron

utterance: Ooft! Your name, Son of Ben Ali? said the White Pig in language that Chunky Riley thought was merely a series of angry grunts and snorts. Ooft! I heard him call for Aaron, and how long has it been since I heard you say to the Red Chatterer in the hickory-tree that there were a thousand Aarons, but only one Son of Ben Ali? Ooft-Gooft! Am I a horse to be ridden? Humph! No man could ride me-it is what you call a Thing. Umph! let it ride you and then talk about clubs. Ooft!
speaker: a White Pig

utterance: Is dat Aaron? Ef 't is, I wish you'd be good enough ter run dat ar creetur 'way fum here, kaze I ain't got no knack fer bein' chaw'd up an' spit out, an'trompled on, an' teetotally ruint right 'fo' my own face.
speaker: Chunky Riley

utterance: What's your name?
speaker: Aaron

utterance: You ought ter know me, but I dunner whedder you does er not. I'm name Riley — dey calls me Chunky Riley fer short.
speaker: Chunky Riley

utterance: Why, yes; I know you pretty well. Come, we'll kindle a fire.
speaker: Aaron

utterance: No suh-not me! Not less 'n you 'll run dat ar wil' hog off. He mo' servigrous dan a pant'er. Ef I had n't er straddled 'im des now he'd 'a' e't me bodaciously up an' dey would n't 'a' been nothin' lef' but de buttons on my cloze, an' nobody in de roun' worl' would 'a' know'd dey wuz buttons.
speaker: Chunky Riley

utterance: Get to bed, Grunter. It is the Lifter the man that is as strong in the back as a horse.
speaker: Aaron

utterance: Gooft-ooft! Let him ride you out as he rode me in ooft! He's no man! Gooft! No bed infor me. When a horse is ridden, he must eat, as I've heard you say, Son of Ben Ali. Gooftooft!
speaker: a White Pig

utterance: Why did you come?
speaker: Aaron

utterance: Des ter fetch word dat Marster wuz layin'off ter git atter you wid Simmons's nigger-dogs 'fo' long.
speaker: Chunky Riley

utterance: All the way through the dark for that? When did you come to like me so well?
speaker: Aaron

utterance: Oh, 't ain't 'zackly dat, I hear um talkin' 'bout it when marster an' dat ar Mr. Simmons wuz walkin' out in de hoss lot. I wuz in de corn crib, an' dey did n't know it, an' I des sot dar an' lis'n at um. An'den dis mornin' I seed dat ar little Marse Abersay, crombie, an' he 'Go tell Aaron quick ez you kin.'
speaker: Chunky Riley

utterance: The child with the crutches?
speaker: Aaron

utterance: De ve'y same, I'd walk many a long mile fer dat white chil', day er night, rain er shine.
speaker: Chunky Riley

utterance: Well, I done what I come ter do, an' I speck I'd better be gwine.
speaker: Chunky Riley

utterance: What pesters me, is de idee dat dat ar wil' hog went 'zackly de way I got ter go. I don't want ter hatter ride 'im no mo' less 'n I got a saddle an' bridle.
speaker: Chunky Riley

utterance: Come! I'll go with you. I want to see the Little Master.
speaker: Aaron

utterance: De dogs 'll fin' yo' track sho, ef dey start out to-morrer,
speaker: Chunky Riley

utterance: Take the end of my cane in your hand and follow it. We'll take a short cut.
speaker: Aaron

utterance: Look yonder!
speaker: Aaron

utterance: What dat?
speaker: Chunky Riley

utterance: The light in the Little Master's window.
speaker: Aaron

utterance: How came it so red, den?
speaker: Chunky Riley

utterance: Red curtain,
speaker: Aaron

utterance: Well, de Lord he'p us! Is we dat close?
speaker: Chunky Riley

utterance: Your way is there, this is mine.
speaker: Aaron

utterance: If that blamed dog is fooling me this time I'll feel like killing him.
speaker: Mr. Jim Simmons

utterance: It is the track dogs.
speaker: Aaron

utterance: Yes; I'm sorry.
speaker: Aaron

utterance: When the big black dog comes stand aside and leave him to me.
speaker: Aaron

utterance: Gooft! not if it's the one that chewed my ear
speaker: a White Pig

utterance: I came this morning by the thunder-wood tree.
speaker: Aaron

utterance: Hide in the grass near there, and when they pass come charging after them.
speaker: Aaron

utterance: A cat, by jing!
speaker: Mr. Jim Simmons

utterance: Oh, if I had you where I could put the lash on you, I'd make you pay for this, you mean, cruel creature!
speaker: Little Master

utterance: Blest ef I don't b'lieve he know you, honey
speaker: Randall

utterance: Why are you so mean and cruel! Oh, I'll make somebody lash you well for this!
speaker: Little Master

utterance: Is anybody ever see de beat er dat!
speaker: Randall

utterance: Do you want to see my runaway?
speaker: Little Master

utterance: Your runaway? I don't understand you.
speaker: Mr. Richard Hudspeth

utterance: Don't you know what a runaway is? Why, of course you do. A runaway negro.
speaker: Little Master

utterance: Ah! a fugitive slave. Yes; I have seen a few.
speaker: Mr. Richard Hudspeth

utterance: But you've never seen my runaway at all.
speaker: Little Master

utterance: He is n't a negro. He's an Arab. I'll let you see him if you promise never to tell. It's a great secret. I'm so small, and—and so crippled, you know, nobody would ever think I had a runaway ?
speaker: Little Master

utterance: Never fear me. Do you keep him in a box and permit only your best friends to peep at him occasionally?
speaker: Mr. Richard Hudspeth

utterance: Oh, no
speaker: Little Master

utterance: He's a sure-enough runaway. He's been advertised in the newspapers. And they had the funniest picture of him you ever saw. They made him look like all the rest of the runaways that have their pictures in the Milledgeville papers, a little bit of a man, bareheaded and stooped over, carrying a cane on his shoulder with a bundle hanging on the end of it. Sister cut it out for me. I'll show it to you to-morrow.
speaker: Little Master

utterance: Well, you must do as I tell you. If I could jump up and jump about I would n't ask you, you know. Take the candle in your hand, go out on the stair landing, close the door after you, and stand there until you hear me call.
speaker: Little Master

utterance: This is equal to joining a secret society.
speaker: Mr. Richard Hudspeth

utterance: Where is your runaway? Has he escaped?
speaker: Mr. Richard Hudspeth

utterance: I just wanted to make the window dark a moment and then bright again. That is my signal. If he sees it, he'll come. Don't you think it's cunning?
speaker: Little Master

utterance: I shall certainly think so if the runaway comes.
speaker: Mr. Richard Hudspeth

utterance: He has never failed yet.
speaker: Little Master

utterance: If he fails now, it will be because Jim Simmons's hounds have caught him, or else he is too tired to come out on the hill and watch for the signal.
speaker: Little Master

utterance: Were the bloodhounds after him?
speaker: Mr. Richard Hudspeth

utterance: Bloodhounds!
speaker: Little Master

utterance: I never saw a bloodhound, and I never heard of one around here. If my runaway is caught, the dog that did it could be put in the pocket of that big overcoat you had strapped on your trunk.
speaker: Little Master

utterance: He's one of us, and I wanted him to see you. He's my teacher. Mr. Hudspeth, this is Aaron.
speaker: Little Master

utterance: If that were put in print, the world would declare it to be pure fiction.
speaker: Mr. Richard Hudspeth

utterance: Fiction is a story put in a book. A story is sometimes called a fib, but when it is printed it is called fiction.
speaker: Little Master

utterance: He's crippled here, but not here
speaker: Aaron

utterance: But all this is not what I called you for.
speaker: Little Master

utterance: Timoleon tore his stable door down to-day and came near killing one of the hands. He is out now. Father will be angry when he comes home and hears about it. Can't you put him in his stable?
speaker: Little Master

utterance: Me? I can lead the grandson of Abdallah all around the plantation by a yarn string
speaker: Aaron

utterance: Well, if you had been here to-day you'd have found out different. You don't know that horse
speaker: Little Master

utterance: He is certainly as vicious a creature as I ever saw.
speaker: Mr. Richard Hudspeth

utterance: I'll show you.
speaker: Aaron

utterance: Don't try any tricks on that horse. He's too mean and cruel. If you can get him in his stable, and fasten him in, I'll be glad. But don't go near him; he'll bite your head off.
speaker: Little Master

utterance: I wish
speaker: Aaron

utterance: You wish what?
speaker: Little Master

utterance: I wish you might go with me. But it is dark. The moon is a day moon. I could tote you to the fence.
speaker: Aaron

utterance: And then what?
speaker: Little Master

utterance: You could see a tame horse- the grandson of Abdallah.
speaker: Aaron

utterance: I'll go to the fence if you 'll carry me. The air is not cold—no wind is blowing.
speaker: Little Master

utterance: Shall I go too?
speaker: Mr. Richard Hudspeth

utterance: I'd be glad.
speaker: Aaron

utterance: It's your turn to tote.
speaker: Aaron

utterance: Who?
speaker: Randall

utterance: The Little Master.
speaker: Aaron

utterance: Don't le' me hurt you, honey. Ef I squeeze too tight, des say de word;'
speaker: Randall

utterance: Whar we gwine, honey? A'on gwine in dar en put dat ar hoss up? Well, 'fo' he go in dar less all shake han's wid 'im, kaze when we nex' lay eyes on 'im he won't hear us, not ef we stoop down and holler good-by in his year.
speaker: Randall

utterance: You er takin' yo' life in yo' han', mon
speaker: Randall

utterance: What a pity if he is hurt!
speaker: Mr. Richard Hudspeth

utterance: Ef horses could talk, I'd up'n' say dey wuz ca'n on a big confab in dar.
speaker: Randall

utterance: Man, what you think? no water, no corn, no fodder since night before last.
speaker: Aaron

utterance: De Lord 'a' mercy! Is anybody ever hear de beat er dat? No wonder he kotch dat ar nigger an' bit 'im! When de rascal git well I'm gwine ter ax Marster ter le' me take 'im out an' gi' 'im a paddlin' - an' I'll do it right, mon.
speaker: Randall

utterance: Man, give me the Little Master, and run and fetch two buckets of water from the spring.
speaker: Aaron

utterance: 'Dey's water in de lot dar
speaker: Randall

utterance: It is dirty.
speaker: Aaron

utterance: He'll not hurt you.
speaker: Aaron

utterance: You are still anxious to punish the poor man who was hurt by the horse?
speaker: Mr. Richard Hudspeth

utterance: I is dat, suh. I'm des ez sho ter raise welks on his hide ez de sun is ter shine-leas'ways ef breff stay in his body. Ef I'd 'a' been dat ar hoss an' he'd done me dat away, I'd 'a' trompled de gizzard out'n 'im. Ef dey's anything dat I do 'spise, suh, it's a low-down, triflin', good-fernothin' nigger.
speaker: Randall

utterance: Whereabouts is that country?
speaker: Abraham Lincoln

utterance: Not far from Georgia.
speaker: Mr. Richard Hudspeth

utterance: Who lives there?
speaker: Abraham Lincoln

utterance: Little Crotchet, Aaron the Arab, Little Mr. Thimblefinger, Mrs. Meadows, and old Mr. Rabbit.
speaker: Mr. Richard Hudspeth

utterance: Of course you believed in the country next door to the world?
speaker: Abraham Lincoln

utterance: To tell you the truth, Mr. President, I felt queerly that night. It seemed as real to me as anything I ever heard of and never saw.
speaker: Mr. Richard Hudspeth

utterance: Get the feeling back, Hudspeth; get it back. I can believe everything you told me about it.
speaker: Abraham Lincoln

utterance: I was with Aaron last night.
speaker: Mr. Richard Hudspeth

utterance: I'm just from the country next door to the world.
speaker: Mr. Richard Hudspeth

utterance: I hope Sherman won't get lost in the country that is next door to the world.
speaker: Mr. Richard Hudspeth

utterance: By what means did you know that the horse had been left without food and water?
speaker: Mr. Richard Hudspeth

utterance: Well, sir, to tell you would be not to tell you. You would n't believe me.
speaker: Aaron

utterance: Oh, you go too far,—indeed you do. Why should I doubt your word?
speaker: Mr. Richard Hudspeth

utterance: It don't fit in with things you know.
speaker: Aaron

utterance: Try me.
speaker: Mr. Richard Hudspeth

utterance: The grandson of Abdallah told me.
speaker: Aaron

utterance: You must be joking.
speaker: Mr. Richard Hudspeth

utterance: Oh, no, he is n't.
speaker: Little Master

utterance: I know he can talk with the animals. He has promised to teach me, but I always forget it when I go to the Swamp; there are so many other things to think about.
speaker: Little Master

utterance: Would you teach me?
speaker: Mr. Richard Hudspeth

utterance: Too old.
speaker: Aaron

utterance: Too old, and know too much.
speaker: Aaron

utterance: It's another case of having a child's faith,
speaker: Mr. Richard Hudspeth

utterance: It Most, but not quite.
speaker: Aaron

utterance: is like this: The why must be very big, or you must be touched.
speaker: Aaron

utterance: There must be some real reason why I should desire to learn the language of animals. Is that it?
speaker: Mr. Richard Hudspeth

utterance: Most, but not quite.
speaker: Aaron

utterance: You must have the sure-enough feeling.
speaker: Aaron

utterance: I see. But what is it to be touched? What does that mean?
speaker: Mr. Richard Hudspeth

utterance: You must be touched by the people who live next door to the world.
speaker: Aaron

utterance: Where is this country that is next door to the world?
speaker: Mr. Richard Hudspeth

utterance: Under the spring.
speaker: Little Master

utterance: Have you ever visited that country?
speaker: Mr. Richard Hudspeth

utterance: No, I'm crippled, you know, and walk only on my crutches. It is far to go, and I can't take my pony. But Aaron has told me about it, and I have seen Little Mr. Thimblefinger - once and he told me about Mrs. Meadows and the rest and brought me a message from old Mr. Rabbit. They all live in the country next door to the world.
speaker: Little Master

utterance: Hello!
speaker: Aaron

utterance: Hello! Hello!
speaker: Mr. Abercrombie

utterance: Hello! Hello! Oh, is n't there some one to hear me?
speaker: Mr. Abercrombie

utterance: Hurt much, Master?
speaker: Aaron

utterance: Not seriously. But the leg that is under the mare is numb.
speaker: Mr. Abercrombie

utterance: Can you walk, Master?
speaker: Aaron

utterance: I think so certainly.
speaker: Mr. Abercrombie

utterance: What is your name?
speaker: Mr. Abercrombie

utterance: I am called Aaron, Master.
speaker: Aaron

utterance: I thought so, and I'm glad of it. Some day I'll thank you; but now-pins and needles!
speaker: Mr. Abercrombie

utterance: Are you still in the woods, Aaron?
speaker: Mr. Abercrombie

utterance: Yes, Master.
speaker: Aaron

utterance: Well, I'm sorry. I wish you belonged to me.
speaker: Mr. Abercrombie

utterance: I'm wishing harder than you, Master.
speaker: Aaron

utterance: What a pity - what a pity!
speaker: Mr. Abercrombie

utterance: Don't get too sorry, Master.
speaker: Aaron

utterance: No; it would do no good.
speaker: Mr. Abercrombie

utterance: And don't blame the Gray Mare for stumbling, Master. The saddle too high on her shoulders, the belly-band too tight, and her shoes nailed on in the dark.
speaker: Aaron

utterance: Good-night, Master!
speaker: Aaron

utterance: Good-night, Aaron!
speaker: Mr. Abercrombie

utterance: When was that?
speaker: Mr. Gossett

utterance: Jimmy! Oh, Jimmy! That old buzzard of a Gossett is in the house. Come see what he wants. And do put on your coat before you come in the house. And wash your hands. They're dirtier than sin. And hit that shock of yours one lick with the comb and brush. Come right on now. If I have to sit in there and talk to the old rascal long I'll have a fit. Ain't you coming? I'll run back before he ransacks the whole house.
speaker: Mrs. Simmons

utterance: You may know I was anxious about you, Simmons, or I would n't be here.
speaker: Mr. Gossett

utterance: You didn't come by when your hunt ended, and I allowed maybe that you had caught the nigger and either killed or crippled him, and-ahem! - felt a sort of backwardness in telling me about it. So I thought I only to say that would come over and see you, if whether you caught the nigger or killed him, he's responsible for it and not you.
speaker: Mr. Gossett

utterance: No, Colonel, I'm not in the practice of killing niggers nor crippling 'em. I've caught a many of 'em, but I've never hurt one yet. But, Colonel! If you'd 'a' gone through with what I've been through this day, you'd 'a' done exactly what I done. You'd 'a' went right straight home without stopping to ask questions or to answer 'em much less tell tales.
speaker: Mr. Jim Simmons

utterance: What did I think when I heard all the racket and saw Sound come out mangled? Well, I'll tell you, Colonel, I did n't know what to think. I never heard such a terrible racket in all my born days. I says to myself, 'I'll just ride in and see what the trouble is, and if there ain't but one wildcat, why, I'll soon put an end to him.' So I spurred my hoss up, and started in; but before we went anyways, hardly, the hoss give a snort and tried to whirl around and run out.
speaker: Mr. Jim Simmons

utterance: It made me mad at the time, but, Colonel, it's a mighty good thing that hoss had more sense than I did, because if he had n't I'd 'a' never been setting here telling you about it. I tried to make the hoss stand, but he would n't, and, just then, what should I see but two great big wildcats trying to sneak up on me? And all the time, Colonel, the racket in the Swamp was getting louder and louder. Pluto was in there somewheres, and I know'd he was attending to his business, so I just give the hoss the reins and he went like he was shot out of a gun.
speaker: Mr. Jim Simmons

utterance: I pulled him in, and turned him around, and then I saw Pluto trying to come out. Now, Colonel, you may know if it was too hot for him it was lots too warm for me. Pluto tried to come, and he was a-fighting like fury; but it was no go. The two cats that had been sneaking up on me lit on him, and right then and there they tore him all to flinders! Colonel, they did n't leave a piece of that dog's hide big enough to make a woman's glove if it had been tanned. And as if that would n't do 'em, they made another sally and come at me, tush and claw. And I just clapped spurs to the hoss and cleaned up from there. Do you blame me, Colonel ?
speaker: Mr. Jim Simmons

utterance: As I understand it, Simmons, you did n't catch the nigger.
speaker: Mr. Gossett

utterance: Do you think you 'd'a' caught him, Colonel, taking into account all the circumstances and things?
speaker: Mr. Jim Simmons

utterance: I did n't say I was going to catch him, did I? I didn't say he could n't get away from my dogs, did I?
speaker: Mr. Gossett

utterance: Supposing you had, would you 'a' done it? I ain't never heard of you walking in amongst a drove of wildcats to catch a nigger.
speaker: Mr. Jim Simmons

utterance: And so you didn't catch him; and your fine dogs are finer now than they ever were?
speaker: Mr. Gossett

utterance: Well, Colonel, it's just like I tell you.
speaker: Mr. Jim Simmons

utterance: You've saved your $30, hain't you?
speaker: Mrs. Simmons

utterance: Why er yes'm but
speaker: Mr. Gossett

utterance: No buts about it. If you ain't changed mightily, you think a heap more of $30 in your pocket than you do of a nigger in the bushes. Jimmy don't owe you nothin', does he?
speaker: Mrs. Simmons

utterance: Well er no'm.
speaker: Mr. Gossett

utterance: No, he don't, and if he did I'd quit him right now- - this very minute. And what Jimmy wants to go trolloping about the country trying to catch the niggers drive to the woods is more 'n I can tell to save my life. Why, if he was to catch your runthey would n't stay at home no you away niggers longer than the minute you took the ropes off 'em.
speaker: Mrs. Simmons

utterance: Oh, hush up, Jimmy!
speaker: Mrs. Simmons

utterance: You know I'm telling nothing but the truth. There ain't a living soul in this country that don't know a Gossett nigger as far as they can see him.
speaker: Mrs. Simmons

utterance: What are the ear-marks, ma'am?
speaker: Mr. Gossett

utterance: Ear-marks? Ear-marks? Hide-marks, you better say. Why, they 've been abused and half fed till they are ashamed to look folks in the face, and I don't blame 'em. They go sneaking and shambling along and look meaner than sin. And 't ain't their own meanness that shows in 'em. No! Not by a long sight. I'll say that much for the poor creeturs.
speaker: Mrs. Simmons

utterance: Well, Simmons, I just called to see what luck you 'd had this morning. My time's up. I must be going.
speaker: Mr. Gossett

utterance: I say, Simmons! She's a scorcher, ain't she?
speaker: Mr. Gossett

utterance: A right warm one, Colonel, if I do say it myself.
speaker: Mr. Jim Simmons

utterance: But, Colonel, before you get clean away, let's have a kind of understanding about this matter.
speaker: Mr. Jim Simmons

utterance: About what matter?
speaker: Mr. Gossett

utterance: About this talk of Jenny's. I'll go this far-I'll say that I'm mighty sorry it wasn't somebody else that done the talkin', and in somebody else's house. But sence it was Jenny, it can't be holp. If what she said makes you feel tired-sort of weary like when you begin to think about it, jest bear in mind, Colonel, that I hold myself both personally and individually responsible for everything Jenny has said to-day, and everything she may say hereafter.
speaker: Mr. Jim Simmons

utterance: Why, of course, Simmons, we all have to stand by the women folks. I understand that. But blamed if I'd like to be in your shoes.
speaker: Mr. Gossett

utterance: Well, Colonel, they fit me like a glove.
speaker: Mr. Jim Simmons

utterance: Jimmy, you didn't go and apologize to that old buzzard for what I said, did you?
speaker: Mrs. Simmons

utterance: They'll catch you to-night, sure
speaker: Little Crotchet

utterance: No, Little Master, not to-night. Not while I'm with the grandson of Abdallah.
speaker: Aaron

utterance: Oh, I see! you'll stay in his stable. Good! I'll bring you your breakfast in the morning.
speaker: Little Crotchet

utterance: No, Little Master! This will do. I'll not take the basket to-night. I'll put the victuals in my wallet.
speaker: Aaron

utterance: Nigger man! You better not try to slip off to Spivey's dis night.
speaker: Turin

utterance: How come, I like ter know?
speaker: Uncle Fountain

utterance: Patterollers on de hill yander
speaker: Turin

utterance: How you know?
speaker: Uncle Fountain

utterance: I done seed um.
speaker: Turin

utterance: What dey doin' out dar?
speaker: Uncle Fountain

utterance: Ketchin' grasshoppers, I speck!
speaker: Turin

utterance: Ef you fool wid me, nigger, I'll make Marster sen' you in de lot dar an' move dat ar' wil' hoss to his new stable.
speaker: Negro

utterance: Marster was made 'fo' you wuz de maker
speaker: Negro

utterance: Ding 'em! they're always and eternally frolicking on this place. No wonder they ain't able to do no more work in the daytime!
speaker: George Gossett

utterance: So! that is the welcome you give to all who may come to make you comfortable.
speaker: Aaron

utterance: Change places with me, Son of Ben Ali, and then see who will warn all comers. Why, the ox has better treatment, and the plow mule is pampered. What am I that my food should be thrown at me through the cracks? The man that fed me comes no more.
speaker: Timoleon

utterance: He is where your teeth and your temper put him, Grandson of Abdallah. But there is to be a change. This night you go to your new house, where everything is fresh and clean and comfortable. And you are to learn to hold a bit in your mouth and a man on your back, as Abdallah before you did.
speaker: Aaron

utterance:
That is nothing, Son of Ben Ali. Then I can gallop, and smell the fresh air from the fields.
What man am I to carry, Son of Ben Ali?
speaker: Timoleon

utterance: Let the White-Haired Master settle that, Grandson of Abdallah. This night, before you go to your new house, you are to have a run with me.
speaker: Aaron

utterance: But before we start, Grandson of Abdallah, this must be said: No noise before I give the word; none of the loud screaming that men call whickering. You know my hand. You are to have a frolic, and a fine one, but before you begin it, wait for the word. Now, then, we will go.
speaker: Aaron

utterance:
Grandson of Abdallah, the horses and the man are yonder. Give them a taste of your playfulness. Show them what a frolic is, but cover your teeth with your lips, no blood to-night.
Spare the horses. They have gone hungry for hours, but they must obey the bit. Spare the man, too, but if you can strip him of his coat as he flees, well and good. You will see other men come running. They will be filled with fear.
Give them also a taste of your playfulness. Let them see the grandson of Abdallah when he is frolicsome. But mind! No blood to-night, no broken bones!
speaker: Aaron

utterance: Beelzebub is abroad in the land to-day!
speaker: Preacher

utterance: I believe the thing had wings, and if I did n't see smoke coming out of his mouth when he ran at me, I'm mighty much mistaken. I never shall believe it was n't Beelzebub.
speaker: Patroller

utterance: I was right at him, when he pulled off Monk's coat, and it was a horse, even to the mane and tail. I was looking at him when he turned and made for me. Then I tripped and fell, and just did get to the fence in time to save my neck.
speaker: George Gossett

utterance:
You hear that, don't you, Mr. Fullalove? It pulled Monk's coat off, and then 227 Gossett just had time to get to the fence to save his neck! Why, it's as natchul as pig-tracks.
Every hoss you meet tries to pull your coat off, and you have to run for a fence if you want to save your neck. That's Gossett's idee. If that thing was a hoss, I don't want to see no more hosses. I'll tell you that.
speaker: Patroller

utterance: Well, there are times and occasions -more espeshually occasions, as you may say — when a hoss mought take a notion for to cut up some such rippit as that. You take that black hoss of Colonel Abercrombie's not a fortnight ago he got out of his pen and ketched a nigger and like to 'a' killed him.
speaker: Mr. Fullalove

utterance: Maybe it's that same hoss in the field yonder
speaker: George Gossett

utterance: No.
speaker: Mr. Fullalove

utterance: That hoss is penned up so he can't git out of his stablemuch less the lot if so be some un ain't took and gone and turned him out and led him to the field. And if that had 'a' been done you could 'a' heard him squealin' every foot of the way.
speaker: Mr. Fullalove

utterance: If anybody wants to call the Old Boy a hoss, they are more than welcome.
speaker: Patroller

utterance: Boys, if any of you have got the idee that the Old Boy was after you, you 'd better stay as fur from this stillhouse as you can, and try to act as if you had souls for to save. What have you done with your hosses?
speaker: Mr. Fullalove

utterance: We could n't tote 'em, and so we had to leave 'em. What I hate about it is that I took a fool notion and rode pap's horse to-night. He'll be hot as pepper.
speaker: George Gossett

utterance: Ain't you going for to make some sorter effort to git your hosses out of the field?
speaker: Mr. Fullalove

utterance: He can have my hoss and welcome.
speaker: Patroller

utterance: I would n't go in that field, not for forty horses
speaker: Patroller

utterance: I might go there for forty horses, but I'll not go back for one, even though it's pap's.
speaker: George Gossett

utterance: Well, it's mighty quiet and serene up there now
speaker: Mr. Fullalove

utterance: He's caught 'em and now he 's skinning 'em
speaker: Patroller

utterance: What is the noise about, Lucy?
speaker: Mr. Abercrombie

utterance: Dat what I wanter know, Marster. It soun' ter me like dat ar hoss done got loose agin.
speaker: Mammy Lucy

utterance: Go out to the pasture there, and see what the trouble is.
speaker: Mr. Abercrombie

utterance: Yasser, yasser!
speaker: Randall and Turin

utterance: I know mighty well dat Marster don't want us ter run up dar where we might git hurted
speaker: Turin

utterance: Dat he don't!
speaker: Randall

utterance: Ef I could git de notion in my head dat Marster don't keer whedder we gits hurted er no, I'd mount dis fence an' go in dar an' see who been kilt an' who done got away.
speaker: Turin

utterance: I speck we better not go, kaze ef we wuz ter rush in dar an' git mangled, Marster'd sholy feel mighty bad, an' fer one, I don't want ter be de 'casion er makin' 'im feel bad.
speaker: Randall

utterance:
Who flung dat rock? You better watch 233 out.
Marster comin', an' he got his hoss pistol 'long wid 'im.
speaker: Turin

utterance: 'T wa'n't nothing but a bug
speaker: Randall

utterance: It de fust bug what ever raised a knot on my head
speaker: Turin

utterance: What was the trouble, Randall?
speaker: Mr. Abercrombie

utterance: We des tryin' fer ter fin' out, suh. Whatsomever de racket wuz, it stop, suh, time we got here an' it seem like we kin hear sump'n er somebody runnin' to'rds de branch over yander
speaker: Randall

utterance:
Some of the mules were in the pasture to-day.
See if they are safe.
speaker: Mr. Abercrombie

utterance: Yasser!
speaker: Randall

utterance: De mules all safe an' soun', suh
speaker: Randall

utterance: Dey er safe an' soun', but dey er swyeatin' mightily, suh.
speaker: Randall

utterance: What do you suppose the trouble was?
speaker: Mr. Abercrombie

utterance: dat ar hoss a-squealin'!
speaker: Susy's Sam

utterance: What horse?
speaker: Mr. Abercrombie

utterance: Dat ar Sir Moleon hoss, suh
speaker: Susy's Sam

utterance: That's what Lucy said
speaker: Mr. Abercrombie

utterance: Marster, ef dat ar hoss had er been in dar, me an' Turin would n't er stayed in dar long, an' dese yer mules would n't er been stan'in' in de fence corner up yander.
speaker: Susy's Sam

utterance: Some of you boys see if he is in his stable
speaker: Mr. Abercrombie

utterance: He ain't dar, Marster!
speaker: Negroes

utterance: See if he is in his new stable
speaker: Mr. Abercrombie

utterance: Yasser! yasser! He in dar, Marster; he sho is. He in dar an' eatin' away same like he been dar dis long time.
speaker: Negroes

utterance: See if the key is in the lock
speaker: Mr. Abercrombie

utterance: Dey ain't no key in de lock, Marster.
speaker: Randall

utterance: Look on the Little Master's mantelpiece!
speaker: Voice
addressee: Mr. Abercrombie, Randall, Turin, and Susy's Sam

utterance: Where did the voice come from?
speaker: Mr. Abercrombie

utterance: Ask where the key is
speaker: Mr. Abercrombie

utterance: Heyo, dar! Whar you say de key is?
speaker: Turin

utterance: What do you think now?
speaker: George Gossett
addressee: the gentleman who had been inclined to grow merry when the former experience of the patrollers was mentioned

utterance: What do I think? Why, I think it's right queer if the chap we left at the double gates is n't trying to get even with us by riding around like a wild Indian and waving his saddle blanket.
speaker: the doubting gentleman

utterance: Why, man, he's riding a gray horse!
speaker: one of the others

utterance: Did you fellows see It?
speaker: young man

utterance: Which way did It go?
speaker: young man

utterance: Let's get out of here
speaker: young man

utterance: Did you notice that the Thing that was riding the Thing had no head?
speaker: young man

utterance: It certainly had that appearance, but
speaker: the doubtful gentleman

utterance: No buts' nor 'ifs' about it. It came so close to me that I could 'a' put my hand on it, and I noticed particular that the Thing on the back of the Thing did n't have no sign of head, no more than my big toe has got a head.
speaker: young man

utterance: And what was you doing all that time?
speaker: George Gossett

utterance:
Trying to get away from that part of the country. It was the same hoss that got after us that night. I knowed it by the blaze in his eyes and the red on the inside of his nose.
Why, it looked to me like you could 'a' lit a cigar by holding it close to his eyes.
speaker: the other

utterance: I know how skeery you are, and I don't believe you took time to notice all these things.
speaker: George Gossett

utterance:
Skeer'd! why, that ain't no name for it no name at all. But it was my mind that was skeered and not my eyes.
You can't help seeing what's right at you, can you?
speaker: the other

utterance: Son of Ben Ali, I smell strange men and strange horses. Their scent is hot on the air. Some of them are the men that went tumbling about the pasture the night you bade me play with them.
speaker: Timoleon

utterance: Not at this hour, Grandson of Abdallah
speaker: Aaron

utterance:
I am not smelling the hour, Son of Ben Ali, but the men.
If we find them, shall I use my teeth?
speaker: Timoleon

utterance: We'll not see the men, Grandson of Abdallah. This is not their hour.
speaker: Aaron

utterance: But if we find them, Son of Ben Ali?
speaker: Timoleon

utterance: Save your teeth for your corn, Grandson of Abdallah
speaker: Aaron

utterance: What did I tell you, Son of Ben Ali? Look yonder! There is one; the others are galloping farther on.
speaker: Timoleon

utterance: I am wrong and you are right, Grandson of Abdallah.
speaker: Aaron

utterance: Shall I ride him down, Son of Ben Ali?
speaker: Timoleon

utterance: Bear to the right, bear to the right, Grandson of Abdallah
speaker: Aaron

utterance: The boys were badly scared, and I tell you it gave me a strange feeling - a feeling that I can best describe by saying that if the earth had opened at my feet and a red flame shot up, it would n't have added one whit to my amazement. That's the honest truth.
speaker: the doubting gentleman

utterance: Were you hunting the runaway?
speaker: Mr. Gossett

utterance:
Why, no, pap.
We were n't doing a thing in the world, but crossing the pasture on our way to the Turner old fields.
speaker: George Gossett

utterance:
Very well, then. Do as I do; let him alone.
If you don't '11 you get hurt. I know what I'm talking about.
speaker: Mr. Gossett

utterance:
Why, pap! ain't he your nigger? Didn't you buy him and pay your money down for him?
Don't you want him out of the woods? And who's going to hurt me, pap?
speaker: George Gossett

utterance: You mind what I tell you. I'm older than you, and when I know a thing I know it. Let the runaway alone.
speaker: Mr. Gossett

utterance: If I'm going to be hurt, I'd like to know who 'll do it.
speaker: George Gossett

utterance: I kin hol' 'im some ef you tired.
speaker: Big Sal

utterance: I won't be tired of that till I'm dead
speaker: Aaron

utterance: I know mighty well how dat is. I des wanted ter hol' 'im. I has helt him.
speaker: Big Sal

utterance: She wants to hold you
speaker: Aaron

utterance: Well, why not?
speaker: Little Master

utterance: He look des like he did when he drapt asleep in deze arms, an' I thank my God fer dat much! But oh, man, what a pity! What a pity!
speaker: Big Sal
